headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, MARVIN D

docs.snippet: EINHORN--Marvin D. August 30, 1920 to April 30, 2014. Actor, television director at NBC, husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather. Much beloved by his family and his theater family. So sad to lose him, full of joy for having known him. Fune...
docs.lead_paragraph: EINHORN--Marvin D. August 30, 1920 to April 30, 2014. Actor, television director at NBC, husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather. Much beloved by his family and his theater family. So sad to lose him, full of joy for having known him. Funeral on Friday, May 2nd at 1pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

docs.snippet: BERNSTEIN--Irving. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Irving Bernstein, a beloved long-time leader of our Long Island community. His exceptional philanthropic traditions live on through the generosity of his cherished family. We exte...
docs.lead_paragraph: BERNSTEIN--Irving. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Irving Bernstein, a beloved long-time leader of our Long Island community. His exceptional philanthropic traditions live on through the generosity of his cherished family. We extend our condolences to Irving's wife, Phyllis; his children, Barbara Bloom (Myron) and Steven (Diane); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

docs.snippet: BEHRMAN--Fay. Passed away at 93 years of age in New York. Her extraordinary life spanned ten decades and three continents. She was a nurse for the Red Cross during and after World War II, during which time she cared for Holocaust survivors in the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BEHRMAN--Fay. Passed away at 93 years of age in New York. Her extraordinary life spanned ten decades and three continents. She was a nurse for the Red Cross during and after World War II, during which time she cared for Holocaust survivors in the Dachau concentration camp. She was whip-smart, elegant, opinionated, vivacious and deeply loyal. Fay loved South Africa (where she was born and raised her family), the arts, fine meals, her walks in Central Park and, above all, her family - to whom she was incredibly devoted. She adored them; and they adored her. Foremost among her devoted admirers were her late husband, Errol, her late son, Darryl and her son, Grant, who survives her. She is also survived by her daughters-in-law, Janine (Alan) and Shelley; her grandchildren Doug (Andrea), Kimmie, Amanda (Zac), and Greg (Caitlin); and her great-grandchildren Josh, Julia, Charlie, and Claire. All of them will miss her dearly, will forever cherish their precious memories of love and laughter with her, and will be graced with the honor of always being able to carry her indomitable spirit with them.

docs.snippet: BERNSTEIN--Irving. During our 50-year association, I cherished my business and personal relationship with my friend, Irving. It included countless meetings and deliberations involving professional, business, and charitable endeavors. He was always...
docs.lead_paragraph: BERNSTEIN--Irving. During our 50-year association, I cherished my business and personal relationship with my friend, Irving. It included countless meetings and deliberations involving professional, business, and charitable endeavors. He was always the gentleman; the calm and deliberate negotiator, and the peacemaker. I am grateful to Irving for teaching me these qualities of leadership. Rest in peace, my friend. Irwin Hochberg

docs.snippet: BERKE--Arnold, born November 15, 1923, died April 27, 2014 in Redding, CT. Son of the late George and Ella Berkowitz. Survived by his wife Marjorie; children George, Gregory and Debbie (Fitts); granddaughter Lyndsey Fitts and sister Regina Brauer ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BERKE--Arnold, born November 15, 1923, died April 27, 2014 in Redding, CT. Son of the late George and Ella Berkowitz. Survived by his wife Marjorie; children George, Gregory and Debbie (Fitts); granddaughter Lyndsey Fitts and sister Regina Brauer and children. His spirit sails free on gentle wind. Service Saturday, May 3, 2014, 4:30pm, Unitarian Church of Westport, CT.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUKE, ANTHONY DREXEL SR.

docs.snippet: DUKE--Anthony Drexel Sr.,died peacefully in Gainesville, Florida, on April 30. He was 95. Tony Duke Sr. founded Boys and Girls Harbor in 1937 and served as its president and board chairman for many decades. The values he instilled in Harbor alumni...
docs.lead_paragraph: DUKE--Anthony Drexel Sr.,died peacefully in Gainesville, Florida, on April 30. He was 95. Tony Duke Sr. founded Boys and Girls Harbor in 1937 and served as its president and board chairman for many decades. The values he instilled in Harbor alumni were inspired in him at an early age at St. Paul's School, in Concord, NH, where he was a leader of the class of 1937. He later attended Princeton University, cutting his education short to join the US Navy. In his distinguished military career he was Commanding Officer of the USS LST 530 at Normandy and an LST Division Commander in the Pacific. He was awarded three battle stars and the Bronze Star. He later made missions to Vietnam for the International Rescue Committee, of which he was a board member. In 1980 he sailed to Cuba during the 1980 Mariel refugee crisis. Mr. Duke was a former vice chairman of the board of trustees of Duke University and a board member of many organizations throughout his life. He was the recipient of numerous honors, including honorary doctorates from Duke, Drexel, Adelphi and Long Island Universities. He received several Presidential citations for his leadership of Boys and Girls Harbor. Mr. Duke was a tireless advocate for inner-city youth and their families. He was a former commissioner of the New York City Youth Board and was active with Big Brothers, the Henry Street Settlement and many others. He was the son of Cordelia Drexel Biddle and Angier Buchanan Duke, and the brother of Ambassador Angier Biddle Duke. They were the grandsons of Benjamin N. Duke, who with his brother, James, heavily endowed Trinity College, which became Duke University. Mr. Duke is survived by his widow, Maria de Lourdes Alcebo, and ten children: Anthony Drexel Duke, Jr., Nicholas Rutgers Duke, Sr., Cordelia Duke Jung, Josephine Duke Brown, December Duke McSherry, John Ordway Duke, Douglas Drexel Duke, Lulita Duke Reed, Washington Alcebo Duke, and James Buchanan Duke. His son, Barclay Robertson Duke, died in 1989. He had 22 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. A private family funeral service will be held on May 12 at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, LI. There will also be a memorial celebration of the life of Tony Duke in New York City on a date later this spring to be announced. Contributions in memory of Tony Duke may be made to: Boys & Girls Harbor, One East 104th Street, New York, NY 10029.
